content: The "Medicare Ambulance Access, Fraud Prevention, and Reform Act of 2014" includes sections on reforming the Medicare ambulance fee schedule, prior authorization for ambulance transports of ESRD beneficiaries, and requiring ambulance providers to submit cost and other information. The "Medicare Ambulance Access, Fraud Prevention, and Reform Act of 2014" amends Section 1834(l) of the Social Security Act to increase the conversion factor for ground ambulance services, with specific percentage increases based on the origin of transportation. The "Medicare Ambulance Access, Fraud Prevention, and Reform Act of 2014" amends Section 1834(l) of the Social Security Act to increase the conversion factor for ground ambulance services, with specific percentage increases based on the origin of transportation. In rural areas, the increase is 3 percent, and for ground ambulance services not in rural areas, the increase is 2 percent. Additionally, for ground ambulance services in qualified rural areas, the payment rate for mileage is increased by 3 percent. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on modifying the conversion factor for ground ambulance services under the ambulance fee schedule to consider the cost of providing services in urban areas. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will use data to determine costs of providing services in different areas and submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2019 with recommendations for legislation and administrative action. Section 1834(l) of the Social Security Act is amended to establish a process for determining coverage of ambulance services for ESRD beneficiaries. The amended section 1834(l) of the Social Security Act requires a prior authorization process for ambulance services for ESRD beneficiaries. The process includes submitting a valid physician certification statement for non-emergency ambulance transport. The prior authorization process for ambulance services for ESRD beneficiaries includes submitting a valid physician certification statement for non-emergency ambulance transport. The Secretary must respond to a prior authorization request within 7 business days and failure to do so will waive the requirement. The Secretary evaluates the medical necessity of ambulance services by determining if the individual is unable to move without assistance, has a medical condition requiring ambulance transport, or meets other criteria. The Secretary evaluates the medical necessity of ambulance services based on specific criteria determined appropriate. Approved prior authorization requests are retroactive to the date received and valid for 60 days, with a possible extension if deemed necessary. An approved prior authorization signifies medical necessity but does not eliminate documentation requirements for a transport claim. REQUIRING AMBULANCE PROVIDERS TO SUBMIT COST AND OTHER INFORMATION. The Social Security Act is amended to require ambulance providers to submit cost and other information for evaluation of payment rates. The Social Security Act is amended to require ambulance providers to submit data on capital equipment, ambulance capacity, and types of services in different geographic locations by July 1, 2015. The Secretary will identify ambulance service providers and suppliers to submit required information under the data collection system. A 5-percent payment reduction will be imposed for failure to report cost and other data starting July 1, 2016. The Secretary will impose a payment reduction for ambulance service providers who fail to submit required information under the data collection system. The Secretary may periodically revise the data collection system as deemed appropriate. The Secretary will require ambulance service providers to submit information for evaluation of payment rates, consulting with stakeholders for system development. Penalty applies for non-compliance with subsequent data collection. The Secretary will consult stakeholders for ambulance service payment rate evaluation, using appropriate mechanisms.
